Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Computational Studies on Hydrocarbon Rearrangements: From Reactions of Polycyclic Aromatic Hydrocarbons to Tunneling in Annulenes
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanism-A Program of the NSF Chemistry Division supports the research of Professors Claire Castro and William Karney in the Department of Chemistry at the University of San Francisco. Professors Castro and Karney and their students are computationally probing reactions of hydrocarbons that occur over a wide range of temperature: from those that occur during combustion to those that occur at ambient temperature. One goal of this research is to elucidate feasible mechanistic pathways that explain experimental results. The high temperature reactions are relevant to the synthesis of materials such as carbon nanotubes; the lower temperature reactions are relevant to understanding the quantum chemical concept of heavy-atom tunneling, a fundamental aspect of chemical reactions. The project lies at the interface of organic, physical, and materials chemistry. This research is well suited for the education of undergraduate physical science students. The Castro/Karney team is also well positioned to provide education and training for students from groups that are underrepresented in science.

Aromatic hydrocarbons undergo dramatic rearrangements at both high and low temperatures. At temperatures of 800-1200 °C, reaction types of interest include hydrogen transfers, Stone-Wales rearrangements, and vinylidene insertions. The computational study attempts to place the various reactions on a common theoretical footing to compare relative rates and generate a unified picture of reactivity for polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons. The work also aims to clarify structure-reactivity relationships, for example, by evaluating how the degree of curvature influences the different mechanisms for Stone-Wales rearrangement. At lower temperatures, pi-bond shifting in annulenes is known to be facile, and the research explores the contribution of quantum mechanical tunneling. The possibility that large numbers of carbon atoms are tunneling simultaneously are explored by comparing classical and quantum tunneling rates. The work addresses the scope of tunneling in organic reactions. The educational plan includes training physical science undergraduates in computational methods and both physical and organic chemistry principles.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF-funded project involved the computational study of organic reaction mechanisms, and was performed at the University of San Francisco in the laboratory of William Karney and Claire Castro. Molecular systems of interest are those that are especially ?carbon-rich?, which are relevant to fields ranging from formation of environmental pollutants to synthesis of materials with novel electronic properties. In one part of the work, mechanisms of hydrogen shift reactions in radicals and diradicals were investigated, due to their relevance to formation and rearrangement of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs), pollutants produced during combustion. These reactions involve the transfer of a hydrogen atom from one carbon in the molecule to another carbon that is missing a hydrogen. Understanding these mechanisms sheds light on the energetics of such rearrangements and the likelihood of formation of certain pollutants. The majority of the group?s effort focused on the study of tunneling in reactions of organic molecules, where tunneling (a quantum mechanical phenomenon) involves passage of a molecule through a reaction barrier instead of over the barrier (Figure 1).

     The heavier the particle that is moving--e.g. a carbon atom (mass 12) vs. a hydrogen atom (mass 1)--the lower the probability that tunneling will occur. Yet the group?s computational studies suggest there are numerous reactions in which multiple (up to 16!) carbons can tunnel to reach the product, and tunneling through the barrier dominates the reactions at temperatures where those reactions have been observed experimentally. The key property is that the heavy atoms must move only a very short distance for the reaction to occur; i.e. the barrier for the reaction is very narrow. The work expands the scope of such heavy-atom tunneling and opens the door to further exploration of this fascinating phenomenon.

            In addition to the scientific findings, the project has provided research training for 2-3 undergraduates per year. Students have learned state-of-the-art techniques in computational chemistry using industry-standard software, and they have prepared written reports and oral presentations on their results. The students have presented numerous posters and talks on their work at regional and national chemistry conferences, and they have been co-authors on multiple journal publications that have emerged from the project. Five of the 11 students on the project have been women, and six of the eight recently graduated students have gone on to Ph.D. programs in STEM fields.
